title: Cwm Penmachno Miners Walk Route

images.title: Stephen Elwyn RODDICK / Cwm Penmachno
images.caption: Cwm Penmachno. A view of the houses known as, Loranka House, Bron-heulog, and Swch. Beyond the houses is the remains of the Cwm Penmachno Slate Quarry.

images.title: Eric Jones / The Rhiw Fachno Quarry aka Chwarel Cwm
images.caption: The Rhiw Fachno Quarry aka Chwarel Cwm

images.title: Eric Jones / Ty Powdwr/Magazine at Cwt-y-Bugail Quarry
images.caption: Ty Powdwr/Magazine at Cwt-y-Bugail Quarry Ty Powdwr was where the Powdwr Du (lit. "black powder" i.e. gunpowder) was stored. Gunpowder was used in the slate quarrying industry rather than dynamite or gelignite as the former gave a 'gentler' explosion which could dislodge blocks of rock, some weighing tens of tons, without shattering them.

images.title: Eric Jones / The Blaen-y-cwm exit incline viewed from the Rhiwbach Tramroad
images.caption: The Blaen-y-cwm exit incline viewed from the Rhiwbach Tramroad. The exit uphaul incline was a water, and then coal powered, sheave mechanism.The company which owned the Blaen-y-cwm group of quarries paid a toll for moving their finished product to Blaenau along the tramway. The Blaen-y-cwm slate mill can be seen at the base of the exit incline.

images.title: Eric Jones / The Rhiwbach Tramroad above Llyn Bowydd
images.caption: The Rhiwbach Tramroad above Llyn Bowydd

images.title: Eric Jones / View SE across the moorland from the Roman Sarn Helen causeway
images.caption: View SE across the moorland from the Roman Sarn Helen causeway. The twin peaks in the background are Arenig Fach and Arenig Fawr.

images.title: Eric Jones / The head of Cwm Machno
images.caption: The head of Cwm Machno. This photo taken from the edge of the cwm's steep backwall shows the derelict Cae'n-y-cwm farm on the floor of the valley. In the background, and in the next square SH7547, are the village of Cwm Penmachno and the Cwm Machno Quarry.

images.title: Dewi / Summit cairn
images.caption: Summit cairn. The quartz cairn on Moel Marchyria is almost lost in the vegetation. Looking down towards Cwm Penmachno.

description: This North Wales village sits in a remote location at the at the head of the River Machno. It's an interesting area to explore with steep sided valleys and a number of interesting old slate quarries. It's also good for cyclists with The Penmachno Mountain Bike Trail to try. Here you'll find single-track and scenic forest trail, riding high through the Snowdonia National Park. This circular walk from the village explores the hills and countryside to the west of the settlement. On the way you'll visit a series of photogenic old quarries and enjoy some splendid views from the high points. At the western end of the walk you've the option of an extension to visit the lovely Llyn Bowydd. Part of the walk uses a section of the Snowdonia Slate Trail which can be used to further explore the slate quarries and mines of the area.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: Just to the west there's the slate mining town of Blaenau Ffestiniog to explore. Here you'll find a station on the heritage Ffestiniog Railway and the fascinating Llechwedd Slate Caverns. You can use the long distance Snowdonia Slate Trail to visit the site. For more walking ideas in the area see the Snowdonia Walks page.
